newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch outline EU presidency agenda from Jan 1.
newsitem.headline: Dutch outline EU presidency agenda from Jan 1.

text.p: The Dutch Foreign Ministry on Wednesday published an outline summary of the Netherlands' plans for its presidency of the European Council in the first half of 1997 (January 1 to July 1).
The paper will be debated in the Dutch parliament on Thursday, November 28.

The ministry said that the Dutch presidency would primarily be guided by the current European Union agenda, although this did not rule out the possibility that the government could introduce a number of topics of its own.
The following are some of the main Dutch "areas of concern".

* The Netherlands hopes the inter-governmental conference (IGC) will be finalised in Amsterdam next June and will result in reform of the EU's institutions leading to greater effectiveness, openness and democracy. It noted the will to succeed, but warned there could be no guarantee of a successful conclusion by the European Summit on June 16 and 17.
* Issues relating to the run-up to Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) -- budget discipline, Exchange Rate Mechanism, technical and legal issues on introducing single currency/euro.
* Enlargement -- further preparation by countries wanting to join the Union and by existing member states.
* Middle East -- aim for a fair, lasting and comprehensive peace.
* EU relations with Mediterranean countries -- Second EU-Mediterranean Conference to be held in April. Aim is for closer links and cooperation on security, trade liberalisation and democratisation.
* Former Yugoslavia -- as EU president, Netherlands will gain seat on Steering Board for Former Yugoslavia.
* Transatlantic relations -- common lead role for both EU and United States in liberalising world trade.
* International crime and drug-trafficking -- Dutch want to improve practical cooperation in battle against organised crime and drug abuse and trafficking.
* Trafficking in women -- Dutch want conference to agree code of conduct to combat illegal international trafficking in women.
* EU fraud -- Dutch want measures to combat corruption and fraudulent use of EU funds.
* Racism -- Dutch want to set up European observation centre for racism and xenophobia.
* Employment -- Dutch will strive to provide interim report on employment in Europe.
Other issues mentioned...
* Internal market -- simplification and quality of regulations, increasing competitiveness, excise duties.
* Transport -- mobility control, air traffic control, telecoms liberalisation.
* Environment -- carbon-dioxide (CO2) energy tax, implementation of Climate Treaty, bio-diversity strategy.
* Health -- action programme to monitor health in EU.

* Agriculture and Fisheries -- liberalise trade in olive oil and tobacco, farm prices, future of Common Agricultural Policy, new beef market regulations, animal welfare promotion, relationship between fish stocks and fleet capacity.
* R&D -- social implications of the "information society".
* External relations -- liberalisation of basic telecoms services and trade in financial services, preventive diplomacy and conflict prevention in Africa, future of Lome Convention.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040
